message.content:
We need to look only at those entries that “move” fixed‐asset funds – namely the cash outlays recorded as “Fixed Assets Purchase.” (The “Initial … Fixed Assets” entry is not included because it is part of the initial capital set–up.) In our data the only investing transactions are the ones whose “type” is “Fixed Assets Purchase.” In our very long table these occur as follows (all amounts are reported as cash disbursements so they are “outflows,” i.e. negative in the cash–flow statement):

• One Fixed Assets Purchase entry with an amount of 73,907.19  
• One Fixed Assets Purchase entry with an amount of 171,448.09  
• One Fixed Assets Purchase entry with an amount of 92,277.65  
• One Fixed Assets Purchase entry with an amount of 191,303.24

We sum these amounts:

  73,907.19 + 171,448.09 = 245,355.28  
  245,355.28 + 92,277.65 = 337,632.93  
  337,632.93 + 191,303.24 = 528,936.17

Since these are cash outflows (money used to purchase fixed assets), the net cash flow from investing activities is –528,936.17.

Thus, in the required format our answer is:

{"solution": {"Net Cash Flow from Investing Activities": "-528936.17"}}
